newsitem.title: UK: OPTIONS - Put options crossed in BSkyB.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Put options crossed in BSkyB.

text.p: UK traded options business dried up by early afternoon on Wednesday as underlying stocks failed to generate much follow-through activity, dealers said.
Some general interest was shown in banks although satellite television company British Sky Broadcasting attracted the biggest deal.

This was the purchase of around 2,500 June 600 puts at prices between 18p and 20p, some of which was sold in a crossed trade. The company announced slightly weaker than expected third quarter pre-tax profits of 81.6 million stg.
By 1420 GMT, BSkyB shares were up 8p to 603-1/2p.

In the banking sector, National Westminster Bank was wanted by one trader buying puts and calls in a strangle strategy expecting share price volatility to increase so that option premiums will rise and the position can then be sold at a profit.
The deal was to buy around 300 July 750 puts at 20p as well as 300 July 800 calls at 24p. NatWest shares gained 13p to 764p.
Dealers were talking of a similar volatility deal waiting to be struck in HSBC Holdings. HSBC shares were up 4p to 705-1/2p.

Elsewhere, there was a buyer of 250 May 550 calls at 2p in confectionery and soft drinks group Cadbury Schweppes which was prompted by market chatter of a bid for the company. The underlying shares added 5-1/2p to 522p.

And over in supermarket chain J Sainsbury, one trader bought 250 July 360 calls at 7p, after the company had announced full year results slightly better than expected. The pre-tax, pre-exceptional profit came in at 651 million stg.
